study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the tolerability and efficacy of a food supplement containing chromium, among other ingredients, on glucose and lipid metabolism in individuals with mildly impaired fasting blood glucose.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly reduced fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) at one tablet/day but had no effect on other metabolic parameters. No biochemical evidence of kidney or liver toxicity was observed.
population_specificity: 81 individuals aged 18-75 with mildly impaired fasting blood glucose (98-125 mg/dL).
effective_dosage: One or two tablets/day (groups 1 and 2, respectively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of selenium on chromium uptake and associated mechanisms in the arsenic-hyperaccumulator plant Pteris vittata.
results_summary: P. vittata effectively accumulated chromium, primarily in roots as insoluble chromite (CrIII), with selenium enhancing Cr uptake by reducing oxidative stress. Neither Cr nor Se upregulated key transporters, suggesting alternative mechanisms for Cr accumulation.
population_specificity: Pteris vittata (arsenic-hyperaccumulator plant)
effective_dosage: 10 or 100 μM chromate (CrVI) and 1 μM selenate

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cardioprotective effects of α-asarone against hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI))-induced myocardial oxidative damage in mice.
results_summary: α-asarone significantly reduced markers of myocardial damage (CK-MB, Troponin I), lipid peroxidation (MDA), and inflammatory biomarkers (TNF-α, IL-1β), while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity (CAT, SOD) and upregulating PPAR-γ, thereby mitigating Cr(VI)-induced cardiotoxicity.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to Cr(VI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the corrosion-electrochemical properties and microhardness of chromium-aluminum coatings on Ti-6Al-4V alloy compared to the uncoated alloy.
results_summary: The study found that chromium-aluminum coatings increased microhardness by 2.3 times and demonstrated improved corrosion resistance in aggressive environments, making them suitable for practical applications in titanium products.
population_specificity: Ti-6Al-4V titanium alloy samples (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (diffusion coating parameters like temperature and saturation time varied but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental conditions varied but duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Fucus vesiculosus as a biosorbent for removing Cr(III) ions from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The study found that Fucus vesiculosus effectively removed Cr(III) ions, with optimal conditions including a pH of 5, a biosorbent dose of 4.0 g/L, and a contact time of 90 minutes, achieving up to 98.9% removal. The biosorption capacity was 14.12 mg/g, and the process fit the Langmuir equilibrium isotherm model.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions containing Cr(III) ions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of trivalent chromium (Cr III) in treating rheumatoid arthritis (RA) compared to baricitinib.
results_summary: Cr III showed superior improvements in disease activity scores (DAS28-CRP, DAS28-ESR) and ultrasound measures (GLOESS, SH, PDUS, joints effusions) compared to baricitinib, with fewer side effects.
population_specificity: RA patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate cost-effective methods for reducing chromium (Cr+6) from polluted water using chemically and bacterially treated agro-waste.
results_summary: The study found that chemically and bacterially treated agro-waste significantly improved chromium adsorption, achieving a maximum 74% reduction under optimized conditions (HCl 4.52 N, NaOH 3.53 N, bacterial suspension 7.41%, and 14.32 min interaction time).
population_specificity: Polluted water effluent (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: HCl 4.52 N, NaOH 3.53 N, bacterial suspension 7.41%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective effects of chrysin against cyclophosphamide-induced cardiotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Chrysin dose-dependently improved cardiac function, reduced serum cardiac injury markers, restored regulatory T cell expression, attenuated apoptosis, and suppressed inflammatory responses, with the highest dose (100 mg/kg) showing the most significant effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 25, 50, or 100 mg/kg orally for 7 days before and 7 days after CP administration
study_duration: 14 days (7 days pre- and post-CP injection)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chrysin-loaded Maillard nanoparticles (P@CMPs) for targeted oral drug delivery in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) therapy, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and hyperoxia properties.
results_summary: P@CMPs effectively encapsulated chrysin (96% efficiency, 16% loading capacity), mitigated inflammation, suppressed proinflammatory cytokines, and enhanced MUC2 expression in a colitis mouse model, demonstrating targeted delivery and prolonged retention in inflamed colonic regions.
population_specificity: Dextran sodium sulfate-induced colitis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of MXene-based composites in removing toxic chromium (Cr (VI)) from water through adsorption and photocatalysis.
results_summary: MXene-based composites demonstrated high removal efficiency for Cr (VI), with adsorption capacities of 100-1500 mg g-1 and degradation percentages of 80-100%. The study highlighted their dual role as adsorbents and photocatalysts but noted limitations like instability and regeneration challenges.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on water treatment applications).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on material performance, not dosage).
study_duration: Not specified (study did not mention intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an electrocoagulation model for hexavalent chromium reduction and precipitation using iron electrodes, focusing on operational parameters for Cr(VI) removal.
results_summary: The study developed a batch reactor model for Cr(VI) removal, validated with experimental data, and suggested design parameters for flow-through electrocoagulation reactors treating Cr(VI) concentrations of 10-50 mg/L. The model integrated ionic transport and chemical reactions, with recommended current densities of 0.05-0.3 mA/cm².
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory/model study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Chrysin's therapeutic effects on endothelial inflammation in a Kawasaki disease (KD) mouse model and elucidate its molecular mechanisms, particularly its role in the NFAT2 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced coronary artery inflammation in KD mice, decreasing inflammatory cell infiltration and cytokine levels (IL-6, IL-17, TNFα, MCP-1). In vitro, it protected against TNFα-induced endothelial injury by lowering IL-6, IL-8, IL-23, ICAM-1, and VCAM-1, primarily via the NFAT2 pathway.
population_specificity: KD mouse model and TNFα-stimulated human coronary artery endothelial cells (HCAECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer potential of newly synthesized chrysin-1,3,5-triazine derivatives, comparing their efficacy to cisplatin and chrysin.
results_summary: Some chrysin-1,3,5-triazine derivatives exhibited superior anti-cancer activity compared to cisplatin and chrysin, particularly against HeLa cervical cancer cells. Compound 4c showed strong antiproliferative effects in vitro and in vivo, inhibiting tumor growth and activating apoptotic pathways via PI3K and Caspase-3 modulation.
population_specificity: Cancer cell lines (MDA-MB-231, HeLa, HCCLM3, HCT116) and HeLa tumor xenografts in vivo.
effective_dosage: IC50 values provided (e.g., 9.86 ± 0.37 μM for compound 4c against HeLa cells), but specific dosage for in vivo use not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin induces autophagy in SHED cells and its potential role in modulating stem cell function.
results_summary: Chrysin at 20 μM increased autophagy-related proteins (LC3-II, Beclin-1) and autophagic vesicles while decreasing p62 levels, suggesting enhanced autophagy. It also induced slight apoptosis but maintained SHED cell proliferation and differentiation potential.
population_specificity: Stem cells from human exfoliated deciduous teeth (SHED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant, anti-apoptotic, and anti-inflammatory effects of Chrysin against gentamicin-induced nephrotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Chrysin protected renal tissues from gentamicin-induced damage by normalizing renal markers, reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, and improving histopathological outcomes.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effects of Chrysin on ulcerative colitis, focusing on its anti-inflammatory properties and gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced weight loss, disease activity scores, serum TNF-α levels, and histological colon damage in DSS-induced mice. It also altered gene expression in NF-κB and IL-17 pathways, shifted gut microbiota populations, and changed colon metabolites.
population_specificity: DSS-induced ulcerative colitis model in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chrysin-loaded PLGA nanoparticles in counteracting cisplatin-induced toxicity in submandibular salivary glands.
results_summary: Chr-loaded PLGA NPs demonstrated significant in vivo effectiveness in mitigating cisplatin-induced toxicity in submandibular salivary glands compared to pure Chr and blank NPs. The study suggests Chr-loaded PLGA NPs as a promising therapy to reduce chemotherapy-related adverse effects.
population_specificity: Albino rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the use of nanocarriers to improve the solubility, bioavailability, and targeted delivery of chrysin, focusing on its pharmacological properties and potential clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that nanocarriers, particularly polymer-based NPs like PLGA, significantly enhance chrysin's solubility, bioavailability, and tumor-targeted delivery, improving its anticancer effects by modulating key signaling pathways in tumorigenesis. Lipid-based and inorganic nanocarriers also showed promise in enhancing chrysin delivery.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiproliferative and anti-migratory effects of chrysin on various human cervical cancer cell lines, including HPV-positive and HPV-negative types, compared to non-cancerous HaCaT cells.
results_summary: Chrysin selectively inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis in all cervical cancer cell lines tested while minimally affecting HaCaT cells. It also caused mitochondrial redox imbalance and significantly reduced cancer cell migration and invasion.
population_specificity: Human-derived cervical cancer cell lines (C33A, HeLa, SiHa, CaSKi) and non-cancerous HaCaT cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether encapsulating chrysin (CR) in a GA-GMS hydrogel could effectively target hypoxia in ulcerative colitis (UC) and restore colonic tissue damage.
results_summary: The CR@GA-GMS hydrogel demonstrated enzyme-responsive release of CR, restored DSS-induced colonic tissue damage, downregulated HIF-1α-mediated NLRP3 inflammasome signaling, and upregulated MUC2 production.
population_specificity: Study focused on an in vivo model of ulcerative colitis (specific human or animal details not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether chrysin nanocrystals could protect against thyroid gland hormone disruption and histological damage caused by chlorpyrifos exposure in male rats.
results_summary: Chrysin nanocrystals did not prevent the reduction in T3 and T4 levels caused by chlorpyrifos, nor did they mitigate oxidative stress or histological damage in the thyroid gland. No significant changes in TSH levels or oxidative biomarkers were observed.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover the molecular mechanisms by which Chrysin exerts its anti-breast cancer effects, identifying key targets and pathways involved.
results_summary: The study identified 140 intersection targets between Chrysin and breast cancer, with ten core targets (TP53, JUN, HIF1A, ALB, CASP3, STAT3, BCL2, TNF, AKT1, IL6) showing stable binding to Chrysin. Functional analysis linked these targets to prostate cancer and IL17 signaling pathways, suggesting Chrysin's potential efficacy in breast cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (in silico and molecular docking analysis, no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore Chrysin-loaded PLA nanoparticles as a targeted therapy for pancreatic cancer stem cells by manipulating the Notch pathway and improving drug delivery.
results_summary: The study suggests that Chrysin-loaded PLA nanoparticles could enhance the bioavailability and effectiveness of gemcitabine in pancreatic cancer cells, potentially contributing to novel treatment approaches.
population_specificity: Pancreatic cancer stem cells (CSCs) with aberrant Notch signaling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a new chrysin derivative, HYS-072, as a therapeutic agent for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) by assessing its ability to induce apoptosis and autophagy in cancer cells.
results_summary: HYS-072 demonstrated micromolar inhibition of MDA-MB-231 cells (IC50 = 3.3 μM), triggered apoptosis and autophagy via modulation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, and suppressed tumor growth in a xenograft model.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells (MDA-MB-231) and a xenograft mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HE-chrysin, a derivative of chrysin, possesses antioxidant and anti-melanogenic properties in vitro and in silico.
results_summary: HE-chrysin demonstrated enhanced antioxidant capacity and significantly reduced melanin production by suppressing tyrosinase activity without cytotoxicity at 2.5 μM. Molecular docking confirmed its inhibitory interaction with key tyrosinase residues and Cu+ ions, outperforming arbutin in binding affinity.
population_specificity: B16F10 murine melanoma cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anxiolytic-like effects of Chrysin in preclinical models and explore its potential mechanism of action involving γ-aminobutyric acid A receptors.
results_summary: Chrysin showed a biphasic dose-response in zebrafish, with anxiolytic-like effects at low doses (1 mg/kg) and anxiogenic-like effects at high doses (10 mg/kg). Its anxiolytic effects were blocked by picrotoxin, suggesting interaction with GABA-A receptors, particularly α5 subunits.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (preclinical model)
interactions: Picrotoxin (GABA-A receptor antagonist) blocked Chrysin's anxiolytic effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of chrysin against amyloid-beta-induced IL-17 signaling and memory decline in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Chrysin at oral doses of 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg alleviated Aβ1-42-induced memory decline, oxidative stress, and inflammation, and downregulated IL-17-mediated signaling in the brain.
population_specificity: Male BALB/c mice exposed to intranasal Aβ1-42.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg orally in 0.5% sodium carboxy methyl cellulose suspension.
study_duration: 7 days of chrysin administration following 5 days of Aβ1-42 exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-obesity effects of chrysin in high-fat diet-induced obese rats and compare its impact to physical activity (swimming).
results_summary: Chrysin reduced weight gain, hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance in obese rats, likely through anti-inflammatory and antioxidative mechanisms. Physical activity was more effective than chrysin alone, but combining both showed the best anti-obesity results.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism by which chrysin improves memory deficits in hypothyroid mice and its effects on the BDNF/TrkB/AKT/Creb neuroplasticity pathway.
results_summary: Chrysin treatment reversed memory deficits and cognitive flexibility impairments in hypothyroid mice, restored protein levels in the BDNF/TrkB/AKT/Creb pathway, and improved synaptic function in the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 female mice with induced hypothyroidism

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize and compare the molecular interactions of chrysin with wild-type and mutated androgen receptors (ARs) and evaluate its cytotoxic effect in an in vitro model of prostate cancer (PCa).
results_summary: Chrysin showed higher affinity for mutated ARs than wild-type ARs and exerted specific cytotoxic effects against PCa cells (DU-145 and PC3) but not non-tumoral cells (RWPE-1), unlike Bicalutamide, which was cytotoxic to all cell lines.
population_specificity: In vitro prostate cancer cell lines (DU-145 and PC3) and non-tumoral RWPE-1 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of targeted delivery of chrysin (CH) and 5-fluorouracil (5FU) using polymer nanoparticles on MDA-MB-231 cells to develop a novel treatment for triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
results_summary: The study found that poly(L-DOPA)-CH-peptide nanocomposites selectively targeted MDA-MB-231 cells, reduced cell proliferation, increased apoptosis, and induced cell cycle arrest in vitro. The targeted delivery system showed promise for inhibiting cancer growth, though animal studies are needed for further validation.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 cells (a model for triple-negative breast cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze biomarkers related to pain in serum and evaluate the analgesic properties of chrysin in a rat model of pain.
results_summary: Chrysin treatment reduced paw licking events, flinching response, and pain scores in rats. It also influenced metabolic pathways (glycine-serine-threonine, taurine-hypotaurine, and arginine), suggesting potential mechanisms for its analgesic effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n = 5 per group)
study_duration: Single dose administered 30 minutes before pain induction

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and study the anticancer properties of a new co-crystal of chrysin and oroxylin A isolated from Oroxylum indicum, focusing on its apoptosis induction mechanism in cervical cancer cells.
results_summary: The co-crystal of chrysin and oroxylin A (1:1 ratio) demonstrated strong antiproliferative effects in HeLa cells with an IC50 of 8.49μM, inducing caspase-dependent apoptosis via ERK inhibition and p38 activation in the MAPK pathway. The co-crystal was more effective than the individual compounds.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer cells (HeLa)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Chrysin's therapeutic efficacy in reducing ovarian toxicity caused by methidathion (MD) in rats.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly repaired MD-induced ovarian damage by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, while improving antioxidant status and restoring sex hormone balance. The study demonstrated statistically significant (p < 0.001) improvements in key biomarkers.
population_specificity: Female rats (24 animals, divided into four groups of six).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could induce immunogenic cell death (ICD) and enhance radiotherapy-induced immunogenicity in melanoma cells.
results_summary: Chrysin alone and in combination with radiotherapy increased immunogenic cell death markers (CRT, HSP70, HMGB1, ATP) and reduced p-STAT3/STAT3 and PD-L1 expression, while also promoting IL-12 secretion in dendritic cells, indicating enhanced immunogenicity. The combination therapy showed a synergistic anti-cancer effect with increased apoptosis.
population_specificity: B16-F10 melanoma cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could bind to DPP-8/9 and potentially inhibit inflammation-driven osteoclastogenesis in RAW264.7 macrophages.
results_summary: Molecular docking identified chrysin as a potential DPP-8/9 inhibitor, and blotting assays confirmed its binding. Inhibition of DPP-8/9 with chrysin reduced inflammatory cytokines and osteoclastogenesis markers.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a green, efficient method for the simultaneous determination of chrysin and resveratrol in complex matrices like human plasma and river water.
results_summary: The study successfully developed an IS-VA-LLME-NaDES method for extracting chrysin, demonstrating high sensitivity (LOD of 161.60 ng/mL), good linearity (0.50-15.0 μg/mL), and excellent precision (%RSDs below 2.0%). The method achieved satisfactory recoveries (97.80%-102.04%) in human plasma and river water.
population_specificity: Human plasma and environmental (river water) samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sedative effects of Chrysin (CHR) and its interactions with diazepam (DZP) and flumazenil (FLU) in a thiopental sodium-induced sleep model, as well as its pharmacokinetics and GABAA receptor binding affinity.
results_summary: CHR significantly reduced sleep latency and increased sleep duration in a dose-dependent manner, with the highest dose (10 mg/kg) showing the most potent effects. Molecular docking revealed CHR had higher binding affinity for GABAA receptors than DZP or FLU, and it exhibited favorable pharmacokinetic properties.
population_specificity: Swiss albino mice
interactions: Synergistic effects with diazepam (DZP) were noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could regulate multiple stages of neurogenesis (proliferation, differentiation, and neurite outgrowth) and identify its mechanisms of action via TrkB and FGFR1 signaling.
results_summary: Chrysin enhanced human neural stem cell proliferation, neuronal differentiation, and neurite outgrowth by activating TrkB and FGFR1 signaling pathways, including downstream ERK1/2 and AKT. It also increased levels of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), FGF1, and FGF8, and promoted neurogenesis in human cerebral organoids.
population_specificity: Human neural stem cells and cerebral organoids (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin nanocrystals (CHN) could protect against Chlorpyrifos (CPF)-induced reproductive deficits in male Wistar rats by leveraging its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: CHN effectively countered CPF-induced hormonal reductions, oxidative stress, and inflammation, while improving antioxidant defenses and preserving tissue integrity in the hypothalamus, testes, and epididymis.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin-functionalized gold nanoparticles (CHR-AuNPs) could enhance the cytotoxicity of paclitaxel (PTX) in lung cancer treatment while minimizing toxicity.
results_summary: CHR-AuNPs demonstrated superior efficacy compared to chrysin alone and showed synergistic effects with PTX, inducing apoptosis, increasing ROS production, and disrupting mitochondrial membrane potential. The combination also modulated key signaling pathways (PPAR-γ, Akt, PTEN, Wnt/β-catenin) implicated in lung cancer.
population_specificity: Lung cancer (specific cell line or model not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer activity of chrysin, alone and in combination with quercetin, in breast cancer cell lines.
results_summary: Chrysin inhibited cellular proliferation in a dose-dependent manner and, when combined with quercetin, enhanced cytotoxicity, induced cell cycle arrest, and promoted apoptosis in breast cancer cells.
population_specificity: MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate a chrysin-based compound (YGT-31) as a novel selective PPARγ modulator for its potential to improve glucose metabolism and reduce hepatic steatosis without the side effects associated with traditional PPARγ-targeting drugs.
results_summary: YGT-31 demonstrated potent glucose-lowering effects, alleviated hepatic steatosis, and selectively improved insulin sensitivity-related markers while reducing insulin resistance and inflammation-linked genes. It effectively inhibited CDK5-mediated PPARγ-Ser273 phosphorylation without causing TZD-associated side effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the metabolism of selenium-chrysin (SeChry) and investigate its cytotoxic effects in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), including its impact on redox homeostasis and potential synergy with other treatments.
results_summary: SeChry induced metabolic shifts in NSCLC cells, affecting pathways like glycolysis, the TCA cycle, and amino acid metabolism, disrupting redox homeostasis. Combining SeChry with glycolysis inhibition or chemotherapy enhanced efficacy, and lactic acid-conjugated nanoparticles improved targeted delivery.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a chrysin-loaded calixarene-cyclodextrin ternary drug delivery system could effectively reverse liver fibrosis in a diabetic mouse model.
results_summary: The chrysin-loaded DDS significantly reduced liver fibrosis markers, restored hepatic structure, and modulated fibrotic pathways, outperforming the control treatment with sulfobutylated β-cyclodextrin alone. It downregulated TGF-β1/Smad signaling and galectin-1 expression while improving liver function.
population_specificity: Adult male CD1 mice with streptozotocin-induced chronic diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Chrysin against diabetes-induced cardiac complications using both chick embryo and rat models.
results_summary: Chrysin improved blood glucose levels, dyslipidemia, and reduced cardiac and inflammatory markers in diabetic models. It also protected against cellular damage and cytotoxicity in the chick embryo model.
population_specificity: Chick embryos and Wistar albino rats with induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chrysin-loaded mesoporous dopamine nanoparticles (Chrysin@mPDA) combined with photothermal therapy (PTT) could enhance the delivery and efficacy of Chrysin for treating estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) breast cancer.
results_summary: Chrysin@mPDA nanoparticles showed high drug-loading capacity and stability, with PTT significantly enhancing Chrysin release. The combination therapy reduced tumor volume and weight, decreased ER+ cells, and increased immune cell infiltration in tumor tissues.
population_specificity: Mouse model of breast cancer (ER+ subtype).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chrysin on the ventral prostate of spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and normotensive Wistar rats.
results_summary: Chrysin increased epithelial height in normotensive rats but decreased it in hypertensive rats, reduced hyperplastic alveoli in hypertensive rats, and lowered oxidative stress markers in both groups. The effects of chrysin varied depending on the physiological context, showing anabolic potential in normal conditions and anti-hyperplastic effects in predisposed animals.
population_specificity: Male Wistar and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), 10 weeks old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocytotoxic potential of cobalt(III) complexes containing chrysin as a ligand for cancer photodynamic therapy (PDT).
results_summary: Complexes Co5 and Co6, containing chrysin, showed significant cytotoxicity against cervical (HeLa) and lung (A549) cancer cells under visible light irradiation, with low micromolar IC50 values (2.3-3.4 μM) and high phototoxicity indices (~15-30). The complexes induced apoptotic cell damage and generated reactive oxygen species (ROS), particularly singlet oxygen, upon light irradiation.
population_specificity: Cervical (HeLa) and lung (A549) cancer cell lines, with low toxicity observed in normal HPL1D lung epithelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could mitigate bortezomib-induced nephrotoxicity by reducing oxidative stress, endoplasmic reticulum stress, inflammation, and apoptosis.
results_summary: Chrysin reduced oxidative stress, endoplasmic reticulum stress, inflammation, and apoptosis while improving renal function and tissue integrity in rats treated with bortezomib.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined neuroprotective effects of kaempferol and chrysin on ischemic brain injury in rats, focusing on anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms.
results_summary: The combination of kaempferol and chrysin significantly reduced brain infarct area, neurological deficits, and expression of inflammatory markers (NF-κB and STAT3), demonstrating synergistic neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Ischemic rat brain model induced by endothelin-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the solubility and anti-schizophrenic activity of chrysin by formulating it as a nanosuspension coated with tannic acid.
results_summary: The study found that tannic acid-coated nanosuspension significantly enhanced chrysin's solubility and anti-schizophrenic effects in mice, outperforming uncoated nanosuspension and free chrysin. The formulations improved demyelination, behavioral deficits, and neurotransmitter balance while reducing markers of neurodegeneration.
population_specificity: Mice with cuprizone-induced schizophrenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate chrysin derivatives as PARP1 inhibitors and assess their potential as therapeutic agents for BRCA wild-type breast cancer.
results_summary: Compound 5d, a chrysin derivative, effectively inhibited PARP1, reduced cancer cell proliferation and migration, induced apoptosis, and slowed tumor growth in a xenograft model.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cell lines (HCC-1937 and MDA-MB-436) and a xenograft model.
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 value of 108 nmol·L-1 for compound 5d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chrysin could mitigate high-fat diet-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress-mediated apoptosis in rat myocardium.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reversed elevated marker enzymes and lipid profiles in HFD-fed rats, improved Nrf2 and its target genes, and reduced expression of ER stress and apoptosis-related genes (PERK, CHOP, ATF6, GRP78, Caspase-3). Immunohistochemistry confirmed enhanced Nrf2 and reduced PERK and Caspase3-7 protein expression.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel chrysin derivative prodrug (C-1) in improving solubility and bioavailability for treating non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that C-1 effectively reduced lipid accumulation, cellular damage, and oxidative stress in NAFLD model cells and improved hyperlipidemia, liver injury, and insulin resistance in db/db mice. Proteomic analysis indicated C-1 enhanced protein expression related to metabolism, and pharmacokinetic studies showed improved oral bioavailability of chrysin.
population_specificity: db/db mice (a model for NAFLD and type 2 diabetes) and NAFLD model cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chrysin and its derivative Chrysin-7-sulfate (C7S) could displace ochratoxin A (OTA) from serum albumin in rats and influence OTA plasma and kidney levels.
results_summary: Chrysin had minimal impact on OTA levels in plasma and kidneys, while C7S significantly reduced plasma OTA levels initially but showed only minor differences after 24 hours. The study highlighted C7S's superior ability to displace OTA from albumin compared to Chrysin.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: Repeated peroral treatment for Chrysin; single intravenous administration for C7S (specific dosages not provided)
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up at 24 hours for C7S)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether chrysin could protect against iron overload-associated hepatotoxicity by examining its effects on redox balance, inflammation, and apoptosis in a rat model.
results_summary: Chrysin reduced hepatocellular damage, oxidative stress, and inflammation, while upregulating protective proteins (SIRT1, PPARγ, Nrf2, HO-1) and suppressing harmful pathways (NLRP3 inflammasome, NF-κB, apoptosis markers).
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced iron overload.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a ternary complex (CHR-OTX008-SBECD) in improving the solubility and bioavailability of Chrysin for treating fibrosis and diabetes complications.
results_summary: The study found that combining SBECD with OTX008 significantly enhanced Chrysin's solubility by forming a water-soluble ternary complex, with no cytotoxicity observed in hyperglycemic in vitro conditions. Structural analyses confirmed non-covalent interactions essential for complex formation.
population_specificity: In vitro (hyperglycemic conditions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antidepressant-like effects of low and high doses of chrysin, investigate its mechanism via GABAA receptors, and compare its efficacy with fluoxetine and allopregnanolone.
results_summary: Both low and high doses of chrysin produced antidepressant-like effects, with low doses acting rapidly and high doses showing delayed but sustained effects. The GABAA receptor mediated the effect of low-dose chrysin, while high-dose effects may involve other systems.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n = 8 per group).
effective_dosage: 1 mg/kg and 5 mg/kg chrysin, administered daily.
study_duration: 28 days, with evaluations at 0, 1, 14, 28 days, and 48 hours post-treatment.
interactions: Picrotoxin blocked low-dose chrysin's effects but not high-dose, fluoxetine, or allopregnanolone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-PEDV activity of chrysin and its potential mechanism of action against PEDV replication.
results_summary: Chrysin demonstrated significant anti-PEDV activity by increasing cell viability, reducing viral copy numbers, and inhibiting viral titer, mRNA, and protein levels. It interacted with viral replicase proteins (3CLpro and PLP-2) through hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic forces, suggesting interference with virus replication.
population_specificity: In vitro PEDV-infected cells (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining chrysin with pyrotinib enhances antitumor efficacy in HER2-positive breast cancer by exploring underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that chrysin combined with pyrotinib synergistically inhibited HER2-positive breast cancer cell proliferation, induced autophagy via endoplasmic reticulum stress, and suppressed tumor growth in mice by modulating the miR-16-5p/ZBTB16/G6PD axis.
population_specificity: HER2-positive breast cancer cells (BT-474 and SK-BR-3) and xenograft mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nasal gel formulation of chrysin complexed with HP-β-CD to enhance its solubility and stability for Parkinson's disease therapy.
results_summary: The optimized nasal gel showed superior drug release and effective permeation through nasal mucosa without harm. Chrysin and its formulations provided significant neuroprotection by improving cell viability and reducing oxidative damage in neuronal cells.
population_specificity: Neuronal cells exposed to oxidative stress (H2O2-induced) and ex vivo nasal mucosa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the anti-fibrotic effects of a supramolecular system combining Chrysin (CHR) with sulfobutylated β-cyclodextrin (SBECD) and OTX008 in hyperglycemic cardiomyocytes and a chronic diabetes mouse model.
results_summary: The combined treatment (SBECD + OTX + CHR) significantly reduced TGF-β/SMAD pathways, MAPKs, and Gal-1 levels in hyperglycemic cardiomyocytes and improved cardiac remodeling and extracellular matrix in diabetic mice, outperforming single-compound treatments.
population_specificity: Hyperglycemic H9c2 cardiomyocytes and male CD1 mice with chronic diabetes.
effective_dosage: In vitro: OTX008 (0.75-2.5 µM); in vivo: OTX (5 mg/kg) + SBECD + CHR administered twice weekly.
study_duration: In vitro: 6 days; in vivo: 22 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of chrysin on cognitive impairment and seizure severity in a PTZ-induced kindling mice model of epilepsy.
results_summary: Chrysin reduced seizure severity comparably to diazepam, prevented PTZ-induced memory impairment, increased BDNF and CREB levels, and reduced apoptotic biomarkers in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Swiss albino male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Chrysin with cisplatin or topotecan enhances anticancer efficacy and reduces side effects compared to single-agent treatments.
results_summary: The study found that Chrysin combined with cisplatin showed synergistic anticancer effects (CI < 1), promoting apoptosis via increased Bax and caspase 8 expression and reduced Bcl-2. However, Chrysin combined with topotecan showed antagonistic effects (CI > 1).
population_specificity: HeLa cells (human cervical cancer cell line)
interactions: Antagonistic interaction with topotecan (CI > 1), synergistic interaction with cisplatin (CI < 1)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify SARS-CoV-2 inhibitors from Scutellaria baicalensis Georgi, specifically targeting the proteases 3CLpro and PLpro, and evaluate chrysin-7-O-β-D-glucuronide's potential as a therapeutic agent.
results_summary: Chrysin-7-O-β-D-glucuronide was found to be a potent SARS-CoV-2 inhibitor with a half-maximal effective concentration of 8.72 µM, binding to key protease sites (H41 of 3CLpro and K157/E167 of PLpro) and altering PLpro conformation. It also demonstrated anti-inflammatory activity by reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-6.
population_specificity: Vero E6 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Chrysin's therapeutic potential for liver and kidney protection against toxicity induced by various harmful substances.
results_summary: Chrysin demonstrated hepatoprotective and nephroprotective effects by reducing toxicity biomarkers, oxidative stress, and enhancing antioxidant levels against multiple toxicants. It shows promise as an alternative treatment for drug-induced liver and kidney damage.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could protect against TBI-induced spatial cognitive decline and explore potential mechanisms, such as synaptic plasticity and BBB integrity.
results_summary: Chrysin (especially 100 mg/kg) improved TBI-induced cognitive decline, restored hippocampal synaptic plasticity, reduced BBB disruption, brain edema, and neuronal loss.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to diffuse traumatic brain injury (TBI)
study_duration: Administered immediately post-TBI (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Chrysin against Paclitaxel-induced hepatorenal toxicity in rats, focusing on inflammation, apoptosis, antioxidant levels, oxidative DNA damage, and histopathology.
results_summary: Chrysin reduced oxidative DNA damage, exhibited anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory properties, and mitigated Paclitaxel-induced hepatorenal toxicity, improving gene expression, histological structure, and immunohistochemical staining results.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin could mitigate DNA damage in retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) cells and reduce inflammation and angiogenesis in choroidal neovascularization (CNV).
results_summary: Chrysin reduced DNA damage, particularly telomere erosion, in RPE cells, alleviated dysfunction, and decreased expression of senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) factors. It also ameliorated inflammatory responses in laser-induced CNV lesions, primarily via the IL-17 signaling pathway and STAT3 activity.
population_specificity: In vitro study (RPE cells) and laser-induced CNV model (likely animal-based, though not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effects of chrysin against cadmium-induced lung toxicity in rats by examining oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and histological changes.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced oxidative stress and inflammation markers, down-regulated endoplasmic reticulum stress and apoptosis markers, and improved lung tissue histopathology in cadmium-exposed rats.
population_specificity: Rats exposed to cadmium-induced lung toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin exerts antitumoral effects in melanoma by modulating angiogenesis, oxidative stress, and DNA damage pathways.
results_summary: Chrysin induced DNA breaks via ATM/Chk2 and ATR/Chk1 pathways, limited angiogenesis, and reduced VEGF-A secretion in melanoma cells, with confirmed effects in a syngeneic B16 melanoma model.
population_specificity: Melanoma cells and a syngeneic B16 melanoma model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of TPGS-b-PCL micelles (CHR-M) as a carrier for chrysin to enhance its anticancer potential, particularly in hepatocellular carcinoma.
results_summary: The study found that CHR-M demonstrated improved encapsulation efficiency (63.50%), drug loading (2.05%), and sustained release (70.70% over 72 hours). It also showed enhanced absorption in Hep G2 cells and lower IC50 values compared to free chrysin, indicating better anticancer efficacy.
population_specificity: Hep G2 cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Drug to polymer ratio of 1:30 (specific chrysin dosage not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin-7G from cherry peduncle extracts could stimulate LDLR gene promoter activity and increase LDLR expression and activity.
results_summary: The study found that chrysin-7G increased LDLR expression and activity, mediated through AMPK activation, suggesting potential benefits for reducing LDL cholesterol levels. The effect was abolished by an AMPK inhibitor, confirming the mechanism.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or cell-based study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether chrysin could mitigate sevoflurane-induced cognitive impairments in aged rats by reducing oxidative stress via Nrf signaling activation.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly alleviated cognitive impairments in sevoflurane-exposed rats, improved performance in memory tests, reduced oxidative stress markers, and activated Nrf signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Aged rats (18 months old) with sevoflurane-induced cognitive impairments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chrysin could mitigate cadmium-induced nephrotoxicity by regulating oxidative stress, apoptosis, autophagy, and inflammation.
results_summary: Chrysin reversed cadmium-induced renal damage by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and autophagy markers while improving antioxidant enzyme activity and renal function.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).
effective_dosage: 25 and 50 mg/kg body weight, administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Chrysin's therapeutic potential and mechanism against high-fat diet-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced liver-fat accumulation, inflammation, and fibrosis in NAFLD mice by modulating AMPK activation and inhibiting NLRP3 inflammasome expression. Proteomic analysis revealed improved protein expression related to energy, metabolism, and inflammation.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with high-fat diet-induced NAFLD.
study_duration: Three months of Chrysin administration following two months of high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate chrysin's role in mitigating cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis in rats and explore the underlying signaling pathways involved.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory biomarkers, stabilized PARP-1 protein expression, and restored cGMP levels in the urinary bladder. It also inhibited key inflammatory pathways (NF-κB/p38-MAPK, NO/PARP-1, and STAT-3), aligning with histopathological improvements.
population_specificity: Rats with cyclophosphamide-induced hemorrhagic cystitis.
study_duration: 7 days prior to cyclophosphamide administration and 7 days afterward (total 14 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-arthritic activity of chrysin and compare its effects with piroxicam in a rat model of CFA-induced arthritis.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly reduced arthritis scores, inflammatory markers, and joint damage while increasing anti-inflammatory cytokines, showing comparable effects to piroxicam. It demonstrated anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties, suggesting potential as an arthritis treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with CFA-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic potential of Chrysin, both alone and in combination with methotrexate, in animal models.
results_summary: Chrysin, especially in combination with methotrexate, significantly reduced paw edema and pain, restored body weight, improved blood parameters, and modulated inflammatory markers in rats with induced arthritis. It also enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity and reduced oxidative stress in liver tissue.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced arthritis.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 100 mg/kg of Chrysin, administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin reduces cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats by inhibiting ferroptosis.
results_summary: Chrysin improved neurological function, reduced cerebral infarction, and alleviated pathological changes in rats. It also modulated iron metabolism and ferroptosis-related markers, suggesting a protective effect against CIRI.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with induced cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury.
effective_dosage: 50, 100, and 200 mg·kg⁻¹ (low, medium, and high doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chrysin (CHR) could ameliorate synovitis and fibrosis in knee osteoarthritis (KOA) and explore its mechanism via the PERK/TXNIP/NLRP3 signaling pathway.
results_summary: CHR improved synovitis and fibrosis in a rat KOA model and attenuated TGF-β1-induced inflammation and fibrosis in synovial fibroblasts. It suppressed fibrosis markers and inhibited TXNIP-NLRP3 interactions.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats with induced KOA and cultured synovial fibroblasts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if chrysin could act as a radiosensitizer to enhance the anti-cancer effects of radiation therapy in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells.
results_summary: Chrysin combined with radiation therapy showed synergistic anti-tumor effects, increasing apoptosis, reducing HIF-1α expression, and altering apoptotic gene expression (increased Bax and p53, decreased Bcl-2). The combination also reduced Cyclin D1 and p-STAT3 levels.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 cell line (a model of TNBC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of chrysin on obesity and NAFLD in rats, focusing on its role in modulating AMPK/mTOR pathways.
results_summary: Chrysin treatment reduced weight gain, hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance in obese rats, boosted antioxidant effects, activated AMPK, suppressed mTOR and lipogenic pathways, and stimulated mitochondrial biogenesis genes in hepatic tissues.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with diet-induced obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the radiosensitizing effects of copper nanoparticles synthesized using chrysin in combination with gamma radiation on tumor suppression in mice with Ehrlich solid tumors.
results_summary: The combined treatment of CuNPs and gamma radiation significantly reduced tumor volume, altered biochemical markers (e.g., decreased ALT, CAT, creatinine, calcium, GSH; increased MDA, caspase-3), and inhibited key proliferation pathways (NF-κB, p38 MAPK, cyclin D1), leading to tumor regression and increased apoptosis.
population_specificity: Mice transplanted with Ehrlich solid tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of chrysin and chrysin nanoparticles (CCNPs) with 5-fluorouracil (5-FLU) on mitochondrial complex II activity and apoptosis induction in pancreatic (PANC-1) and lung (A549) cancer cells.
results_summary: CCNPs showed superior efficacy in reducing enzyme activity, decreasing expression of SDH C and D, SIRT-3, and HIF-1α mRNA, and increasing apoptosis compared to chrysin alone and 5-FLU. Mitochondrial swelling was also significantly affected by CCNPs.
population_specificity: Pancreatic (PANC-1) and lung (A549) cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of nano-niosomes containing chrysin (Chr-Nio) on the SKOV3 ovarian cancer cell line and assess its potential as an improved drug delivery method.
results_summary: Chr-Nio demonstrated higher cytotoxicity than free chrysin in a time- and dose-dependent manner, significantly altered apoptotic gene expression (Bcl-2, Bax, caspase-3), and inhibited SKOV3 cell migration in vitro. Encapsulation in niosomes enhanced chrysin's anticancer effects.
population_specificity: SKOV3 ovarian cancer cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-cancer activities of chrysin, focusing on its potential as an adjuvant in cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that chrysin exhibits anti-cancer effects by stimulating apoptosis, inhibiting tumor growth, and inducing cytotoxic effects in cancer cells, while being non-toxic to normal cells.
population_specificity: Human cells and rats (in vitro and in vivo studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chrysin and/or BM-MSCs on STZ/NA-induced diabetic rats as a model of T2DM, focusing on metabolic and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Chrysin, alone or combined with BM-MSCs, significantly improved glucose tolerance, liver glycogen content, serum insulin, and inflammatory markers in diabetic rats, with the combination showing the greatest therapeutic effect.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with STZ/NA-induced T2DM.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight orally every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing literature on chrysin's effects on gastric cancer, focusing on its cellular mechanisms and antitumor pathways.
results_summary: The study found that chrysin exhibits antitumor effects against gastric cancer cell lines in vitro, mediated through various pathways and miRNA expression. The abstract highlights its potential as a novel therapeutic approach but does not provide specific clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cell lines (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer potential of chrysin when delivered via folic acid-conjugated mesoporous silica nanoparticles, focusing on targeted delivery and enhanced therapeutic efficacy in breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that chrysin-loaded nanoparticles induced apoptosis in MCF-7 cells through oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction, leading to G1 arrest. In vivo, the nanoparticles enhanced tumor regression, restored tissue architecture, and maintained healthy body weight without serious systemic toxicity.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (MCF-7) cells and tumor-bearing mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a chrysin derivative's potential as a multi-target therapeutic for Alzheimer's disease, focusing on metal homeostasis restoration, anti-oxidative properties, and Aβ1-42 aggregation inhibition.
results_summary: The chrysin derivative demonstrated potent anti-oxidative activity, effectively scavenged reactive oxygen species, inhibited Aβ1-42 aggregation, and targeted copper dyshomeostasis. It also showed potential brain availability and oral bioavailability in silico studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of chrysin on lead-induced cognitive impairment and explore potential mechanisms, including synaptic plasticity, inflammation, and neuronal loss.
results_summary: Chrysin improved cognitive dysfunction, restored hippocampal synaptic plasticity, modulated inflammatory cytokines, reduced lead levels, and prevented neuronal loss in lead-exposed rats.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms behind chrysin-induced vasorelaxation in rats' aortic rings and assess its antihypertensive effects in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
results_summary: Chrysin induced vasorelaxation through multiple pathways, including NO/sGC/cGMP signaling, muscarinic and β-adrenergic receptors, and potassium and calcium channels. However, it did not significantly reduce blood pressure in SHRs after 21 days of oral treatment.
population_specificity: Rats (aortic rings and spontaneously hypertensive rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity of chrysin in combination with colistin against Acinetobacter baumannii and assess its potential as a synergistic therapeutic option.
results_summary: Chrysin and colistin showed synergistic effects against A. baumannii by damaging the extracellular membrane and altering bacterial membrane potential. The combination also inhibited biofilm formation, suggesting potential for reduced colistin dosage in treatment.
population_specificity: Acinetobacter baumannii (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of chrysin-loaded nanoemulsion (CH NE) in treating lithium/pilocarpine-induced epilepsy in rats and its effects on neuronal hyperactivity, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation.
results_summary: The optimized CH NE formulation reduced seizure severity, corrected behavioral and histological changes, restored neurotransmitter balance and oxidative stress markers, and modulated microglia polarization and energy metabolism. CH NE enhanced drug delivery to the hippocampus compared to a higher-dose CH suspension.
population_specificity: Rats with lithium/pilocarpine-induced epilepsy.
effective_dosage: CH NE at a dose 30-fold lower than the oral CH suspension (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin (CHR) could mitigate diclofenac (DF)-induced hepatotoxicity by regulating oxidative stress, apoptosis, autophagy, and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress.
results_summary: CHR at 25 and 50 mg/kg significantly reduced oxidative stress, apoptosis, autophagy, and ER stress caused by DF in liver tissue, demonstrating protective effects against DF-induced liver damage.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned in the abstract).
effective_dosage: 25 mg/kg and 50 mg/kg body weight, orally administered for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin enhances the cytotoxicity of YM155 and synergistically suppresses survivin expression in SMARCB1/INI1-deficient tumor cells.
results_summary: Chrysin enhanced YM155-induced apoptosis and synergistically suppressed survivin expression in SMARCB1/INI1-deficient tumor cells, particularly in TTN45 cells, where suppression was observed as early as 6 hours after exposure.
population_specificity: SMARCB1/INI1-deficient tumor cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular and cellular mechanisms of chrysin on bladder tumor cell lines with different TP53 statuses.
results_summary: Chrysin reduced cell viability and induced apoptosis across all cell lines, regardless of TP53 status. In TP53-mutated cells, it also modulated the expression of epigenetic genes (DNMT1, HAT1, HDAC1), potentially enhancing cell death.
population_specificity: Bladder tumor cell lines (RT4, 5637, T24) with varying TP53 statuses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin inhibits tumor progression in hypoxic PC-3 prostate cancer cells by targeting SPHK-1/HIF-1α signaling.
results_summary: Chrysin significantly inhibited 3D cell growth, reduced hypoxia-induced vasculogenic mimicry, and suppressed HIF-1α and VE-cadherin expression. It also induced apoptosis, inhibited VEGF and Bcl-2, and reduced tumor growth in PC-3 xenografts by 80.4%.
population_specificity: Hypoxic PC-3 prostate cancer cells and PC-3 xenografts in mice.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg in xenograft study (in vitro concentrations not specified).
study_duration: Not specified for in vitro; xenograft duration not mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of chitosan-chrysin nano-formulations (CCNPs) as a therapeutic option for pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and lung cancer by inhibiting mitochondrial complex ΙΙ (CΙΙ) and ubiquinone oxidoreductase.
results_summary: The study suggests that CCNPs, due to their improved bioavailability and efficacy, may be promising candidates for treating PDAC and lung cancer by blocking succinate ubiquinone oxidoreductase. Chitosan's properties enhance the therapeutic potential of chrysin.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo study not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chrysin suppresses pancreatic cancer progression through GPER activation and reductions in ROCK1, TAGLN2, and FCHO2 expressions.
results_summary: Chrysin caused cell cycle arrest, decreased cell viability, and delayed tumor growth in a xenograft model. It also reduced Ki-67 and c-Myc expressions and lowered ROCK1, TAGLN2, and FCHO2 levels, which are linked to poor pancreatic cancer survival.
population_specificity: MIA PaCa-2 cells and a xenograft model (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether chrysin enhances the cytotoxic effects of TRAIL on osteosarcoma cells (Saos-2 and MG-63) by sensitizing them to apoptosis.
results_summary: Chrysin synergistically increased TRAIL-induced cytotoxicity, amplified caspase 8 activity, and reduced expression of antiapoptotic genes, suggesting it sensitizes osteosarcoma cells to TRAIL-induced apoptosis via the death receptor pathway.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma cell lines (Saos-2 and MG-63)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Chrysin-loaded folate-bound chitosan solid lipid nanoparticles (CHY-SCF-NPs) as a potential anti-cancer treatment, particularly for pancreatic cancer.
results_summary: CHY-SCF-NPs demonstrated anti-cancer effects by inhibiting malignant cell lines (PANC, MCF-7, A2780, HepG2) and exhibited antioxidant and anti-angiogenic properties, along with pro-apoptotic effects confirmed by gene up-regulation and cell cycle analysis.
population_specificity: In vitro studies on malignant cell lines (PANC, MCF-7, A2780, HepG2) and normal cells (HFF).
effective_dosage: IC50 values: ~53 µg/mL (PANC), ~55 µg/mL (MCF-7), ~249 µg/mL (A2780), >250 µg/mL (HepG2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and underlying mechanism of chrysin on diabetic nephropathy (DN) in mice, focusing on lipid metabolism and AMPK activation.
results_summary: Chrysin improved obesity, insulin resistance, renal function, and pathological injury in DN mice, while also reducing lipid accumulation, oxidative stress, and inflammation. The study identified AMPK activation as a critical mechanism for chrysin's effects, confirmed by partial suppression of benefits with an AMPK inhibitor.
population_specificity: High-fat-diet (HFD) and streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic nephropathy mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Chrysin's cardioprotective effects against oxidative and ER stress in cardiomyoblast cells and its mechanism via Nrf2 signaling.
results_summary: Chrysin pre-treatment increased Nrf2-regulated gene expression, reduced ER stress markers (CHOP, GRP78), and decreased apoptosis markers (PI3K, NF-κB, caspase-3). It also reduced ROS generation and improved mitochondrial membrane potential, but these effects were abolished when Nrf2 was silenced.
population_specificity: H9c2 cardiomyoblast cell lines
study_duration: 24 hours pre-treatment, followed by 1-hour H2O2 exposure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining cinnamon essential oil (CEO) with fusidic acid (FA) in a nanoemulsion-hydrogel could enhance antibacterial effects against multidrug-resistant bacteria.
results_summary: The FA-NE-hydrogel demonstrated acceptable physical properties for topical use, extended in vitro release, stability for 3 months, and effective inhibition of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, with CEO enhancing FA's antibacterial activity.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant bacteria (no human subjects mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cinnamon, particularly its extracts and bioactive compounds, could act synergistically with infliximab to mitigate inflammation in non-responders to anti-TNF-α therapy.
results_summary: Cinnamon extracts (especially C. cassia) and trans-cinnamaldehyde showed dose-dependent synergistic effects with infliximab, modulating gene expression related to inflammation, apoptosis, and matrix remodeling. The study found differential effects on specific genes, with C. cassia aCE being the most effective.
population_specificity: In vitro study using fibroblast (L929) and monocytic (U937) cell lines.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-dependent effects observed but exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (in vitro study without explicit duration mentioned).
interactions: Synergistic interaction with infliximab noted; no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial mechanisms of cinnamon essential oil (CIEO) and cinnamaldehyde (CID) in vivo using C. elegans and in vitro against common pathogens.
results_summary: Both high (100 mg/L) and low (10 mg/L) doses of CIEO and CID significantly improved locomotion behavior, lifespan, and reduced bacterial accumulation in C. elegans infected with P. aeruginosa. Low doses upregulated antimicrobial peptide-related genes, while high doses suppressed this trend, suggesting involvement of the PMK-1 mediated p38 signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) and in vitro bacterial strains (P. aeruginosa and 4 other strains).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory properties of cinnamon bark oil (CBO) against Penicillium digitatum, a major citrus fruit pathogen, and uncover its antifungal mechanisms at the molecular level.
results_summary: CBO at 0.03% effectively inhibited spore germination, germ tube elongation, mycelial growth, and other fungal activities in P. digitatum. Higher concentrations (exceeding 0.06%) also inhibited green mold rots in citrus fruit, with transcriptomic analysis revealing significant gene expression changes linked to metabolic disturbances and ROS generation.
population_specificity: In vitro study on Penicillium digitatum and citrus fruit.
study_duration: Not specified (abstract mentions 4 h and 8 h treatment periods for transcriptomic analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different cinnamon species on blood glucose control in diabetes and assess study quality and bias in existing literature.
results_summary: Overall, 62% of studies showed statistically significant positive effects on blood glucose control, though ranking systems reduced this to around 50%. Cinnamon supplementation likely has a modest positive effect on blood glucose, with an excellent safety profile.
population_specificity: Human subjects with diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cinnamon powder could improve the quality and mitigate off-flavors in fried chicken drumsticks made from long-term thawed Korean native chicken.
results_summary: Cinnamon powder (0.03% in marinade or 1.35% in batter) reduced lipid oxidation volatiles and increased pleasant aroma compounds, with the 0.03% marinade group (CM) receiving higher aroma scores. The study found that cinnamon effectively discriminated treatment groups and improved sensory qualities.
population_specificity: Fried chicken drumsticks made from long-term thawed Korean native chicken (Woorimatdag No. 1, WRMD1).
effective_dosage: 0.03% in marinade (CM), 1.35% in batter (CB), or both (0.03% + 1.35%, CMB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Cinnamomum verum oil as an inhibitor to restore imipenem susceptibility in carbapenem-resistant Acinetobacter baumannii (CRAB) strains.
results_summary: Cinnamomum verum oil, along with other inhibitors, showed promising results by reducing imipenem MIC by 2-6-fold in 90% of CRAB strains and downregulating efflux pump genes. The effect was confirmed in 24-hour killing kinetics.
population_specificity: Clinical Acinetobacter baumannii isolates from Egyptian ICU patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily cinnamon supplementation (4 g/d) improves glucose control in adults with obesity and prediabetes.
results_summary: Cinnamon significantly lowered 24-hour glucose concentrations, reduced glucose peaks, and decreased triglyceride levels compared to placebo, with no differences in digestive symptoms between groups.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity and prediabetes (mean age 51.1 y; mean fasting plasma glucose 102.9 mg/dL).
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention phase (with a 2-week washout period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of incorporating cinnamon essential oil (CEO) Pickering emulsion into chitosan-based films on physical properties, biological activities, and potential for food packaging applications.
results_summary: The study found that CEO Pickering emulsion improved mechanical and barrier properties, light transmittance, thermal stability, antioxidant activities, and antimicrobial properties of the films, with slow-release behavior extending biological activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on film properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effect of cinnamon supplementation on adipokines and appetite-regulating hormones.
results_summary: Cinnamon supplementation decreased leptin and visfatin levels, increased ghrelin levels, and had inconsistent effects on other biomarkers like adiponectin, glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide, glucagon-like peptide 1, and resistin.
population_specificity: 363 participants, including one study on children and two on obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cinnamon oil as an antibiotic substitute on blood biochemical parameters, antioxidant capacity, and histopathological profiles in growing Japanese quails.
results_summary: Cinnamon oil significantly reduced AST and urea levels, lowered cholesterol, and improved antioxidant capacity (TAC, SOD, GPX, GSR) compared to control and antibiotic groups. It also enhanced intestinal and hepatic histology, suggesting potential as an antibiotic alternative.
population_specificity: Growing Japanese quails
effective_dosage: 0.5 mL and 1.0 mL of cinnamon oil per kg of diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether polyphenol-enriched fractions of cinnamon could enhance the anticancer effects of cetuximab in colorectal cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon-derived fractions, rich in procyanidins and flavonoids, significantly reduced the required dose of cetuximab for antiproliferative activity in EGFR-sensitive colorectal cancer cells. These fractions induced apoptosis through ERK activation and mitochondrial membrane potential impairment.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer cell line E705 (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the synergistic bactericidal effects of RF heating combined with cinnamon essential oil nanoemulsion (CEON) against Salmonella and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The combination of RF heating and CEON enhanced membrane permeability and ROS accumulation in Salmonella, with the major mechanism being significant inhibition of intracellular ATP synthesis. The combined treatment also disrupted multiple intracellular metabolisms, leading to synergistic bactericidal effects.
population_specificity: Salmonella bacterial cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cinnamon powder (CP) could reduce glycemia in diabetic mice by regulating liver glucose metabolism.
results_summary: CP treatment reduced fasting blood glucose, improved glucose tolerance and insulin levels, increased liver glycogen content, and decreased gluconeogenesis precursors. The effects were mediated through AMPKα/PGC1α and PI3K/AKT pathways.
population_specificity: Diabetic mice
effective_dosage: 200, 400, or 800 mg/kg body weight, administered once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral potential of a galangal-cinnamon mixture (GCAE) against Low Pathogenic HCoV-229E as a proxy for SARS-CoV-2 inhibition.
results_summary: The GCAE showed significant antiviral activity against HCoV-229E (IC50 15.083 µg/mL), with rutin identified as the most active compound. Quantum-chemical and docking analyses supported the experimental findings, indicating potential inhibition of coronavirus infection pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro study using Low Pathogenic HCoV-229E (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested as an aqueous extract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of cinnamon supplementation on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Cinnamon supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, Homeostatic Model Assessment for Insulin Resistance, and hemoglobin A1C in patients with T2DM, but did not significantly change serum insulin levels. The findings suggest cinnamon may have clinical potential as an adjunct therapy for managing T2DM.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary supplementation with cinnamon essential oil on growth performance, fatty acid composition, and fillet quality in tilapia.
results_summary: The study found that increasing doses of cinnamon essential oil improved weight gain, reduced saturated fatty acids, increased polyunsaturated fatty acids (especially n-3 and n-6 PUFA), and enhanced fillet quality (hardness, cohesiveness, and reduced b* values and volatile nitrogen levels).
population_specificity: Tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus)
effective_dosage: 0.2%, 0.35%, and 0.5% cinnamon essential oil in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity and mechanism of cinnamon essential oil nanoemulsion (CON) against Pseudomonas deceptionensis CM2.
results_summary: CON effectively inhibited P. deceptionensis CM2 proliferation in a time- and concentration-dependent manner, disrupting membrane integrity, increasing oxidative stress, and causing intracellular leakage. The antimicrobial activity was significantly reduced by glutathione, confirming oxidative stress's role in CON's mechanism.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas deceptionensis CM2 bacterial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential intestinal anti-inflammatory effects of Cinnamomum cassia (cinnamon) in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Cinnamon hot water extract (CWE) improved tight junction barrier function, reduced proinflammatory cytokine expression in Caco-2 cells, and alleviated colitis symptoms in mice, suggesting it may enhance intestinal health.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (in vitro) and colitis model mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimicrobial and anti-biofilm effects of cinnamon oil against multidrug-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae isolates from pneumonic sheep and goats.
results_summary: Cinnamon oil demonstrated strong antibacterial and anti-biofilm effects against K. pneumoniae, with inhibition zones of 35-45 mm, lower MIC/MBC values than norfloxacin, and significant reduction in biofilm-associated gene expression.
population_specificity: Pneumonic sheep and goats in Sharika Governorate, Egypt.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cinnamon on the pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties of amlodipine in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon significantly reduced blood pressure and enhanced the pharmacokinetic parameters (Cmax and AUC0-t) of amlodipine in hypertensive rats, showing a synergistic effect when combined with amlodipine.
population_specificity: Hypertensive Wistar rats
interactions: Enhanced pharmacokinetics of amlodipine (Cmax and AUC0-t) when co-administered with cinnamon

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cinnamon essential oil (CEO) vapor treatment could mitigate chilling injury-induced aroma loss and internal browning in "Feicheng" peaches during cold storage.
results_summary: CEO vapor (50 μL/L) reduced internal browning and restored aroma content in peaches during refrigeration, while also promoting the release of aroma-related volatiles and upregulating genes linked to volatile biosynthesis.
population_specificity: "Feicheng" peach fruits
study_duration: 7–21 days of refrigeration plus 2 days of shelf life

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose-response relationship between cinnamon and glycolipid metabolism in type 2 diabetic patients, focusing on its effects on triglyceride, LDL-C, and HDL-C levels.
results_summary: Cinnamon intervention significantly reduced triglyceride and LDL-C levels while increasing HDL-C levels in type 2 diabetic patients, with dosage influencing TG and LDL-C effects. However, it had no significant impact on fasting blood glucose, HbA1c, or total cholesterol levels.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidepressant effects and mechanisms of a Cinnamon Oil Solid Self-Microemulsifying Drug Delivery System (CO-S-SME) in mice with chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS)-induced depression-like behavior.
results_summary: CO-S-SME improved depression-like behaviors in CUMS mice, increased neurotransmitter levels, reduced corticosterone and inflammatory factors, and modulated intestinal flora composition by decreasing the Firmicutes to Bacteroidetes ratio and altering microbial diversity.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to CUMS to induce depression-like behavior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antioxidative activity of cinnamon oil (CO) in mitigating APAP-induced uterine toxicity in female rats.
results_summary: Cinnamon oil significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (LPO), inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6), and caspase expression while restoring uterine tissue architecture in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Female rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cinnamon on glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) by conducting an umbrella meta-analysis of previous interventional meta-analyses.
results_summary: Cinnamon supplementation significantly reduced fasting plasma glucose, insulin levels, HOMA-IR, and HbA1c, indicating its potential as an anti-diabetic agent for glycemic control in T2D and PCOS patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D) or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which digested cinnamon extract pre-treatment prevents inflammation-related intestinal barrier dysfunction, focusing on claudin-2 regulation and autophagy-mediated degradation.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with cinnamon extract prevented transepithelial electrical resistance (TEER) loss by regulating claudin-2 protein levels, influencing both gene transcription and autophagy-mediated degradation, suggesting cinnamon polyphenols mediate adaptive responses against inflammation.
population_specificity: In vitro model of inflamed intestinal barrier (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antimicrobial, antifungal, antioxidant, and cytotoxicity properties of cinnamon essential oil nanoemulsions versus pure cinnamon essential oil.
results_summary: Cinnamon essential oil nanoemulsions showed higher antioxidant and antimicrobial activity compared to pure essential oil, along with improved cell viability in cytotoxicity tests.
population_specificity: 3T3 cell line (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oral cinnamon extract (Cinn) on glucose transporter gene expressions in the hippocampus and spatial memory in a streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease rat model.
results_summary: The study found that cinnamon extract, especially when combined with insulin, improved spatial memory performance in the Morris Water Maze test and upregulated GLUT gene expressions in hippocampal tissue. The synergistic treatment showed significant improvements compared to individual treatments.
population_specificity: Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats (280±20 g) with streptozotocin-induced Alzheimer's disease model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cinnamaldehyde-rich cinnamon extract (CRCE) on colorectal cancer cell lines HCT 116 and HT-29, focusing on cell viability, proliferation, migration, and apoptosis.
